'''Sufjan Stevens''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|uː|f|j|ɑː|n}} {{respell|SOOF|yahn}}; born July 1, 1975) is an American singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist. He has released nine solo studio albums and multiple collaborative albums with other artists. Stevens has received [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] and [[Academy Award]] nominations.

His debut album, ''[[A Sun Came]]'', was released in 2000 on the [[Asthmatic Kitty]] label, which he co-founded with his stepfather. He received wide recognition for his 2005 album ''[[Illinois (Sufjan Stevens album)|Illinois]]'',<!-- DO NOT CHANGE THE NAME OF THE ALBUM: the album is "Illinois", one track is "Come on Feel the Illinoise": see the Talk page--> which hit number one on the [[Billboard charts|''Billboard'']] [[Top Heatseekers]] chart, and for the single "[[Chicago (Sufjan Stevens song)|Chicago]]" from that album. Stevens later contributed to the soundtrack of the 2017 film ''[[Call Me by Your Name (film)|Call Me by Your Name]]''. He received an [[90th Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] and a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Song Written for Visual Media|Best Song Written for Visual Media]] for the soundtrack's lead single, "[[Mystery of Love]]."

Stevens has released albums of varying styles, from the [[electronica]] of ''[[The Age of Adz]]'' and the [[lo-fi music|lo-fi]] [[folk music|folk]] of ''[[Seven Swans]]'' to the symphonic instrumentation of ''Illinois''<!-- DO NOT CHANGE THE NAME OF THE ALBUM: the album is "Illinois", one track is "Come on Feel the Illinoise": see the Talk page--> and Christmas-themed ''[[Songs for Christmas (Sufjan Stevens album)|Songs for Christmas]]''. He employs various instruments, often playing many of them himself on the same recording. Stevens' music is also known for exploring various themes, particularly religion and spirituality. Stevens' tenth and latest studio album, ''[[A Beginner's Mind]]'', was created alongside [[Angelo De Augustine]] and released in 2021.

==Early life==
Stevens was born in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], and lived there until the age of nine, when his family moved to [[Alanson, Michigan]], in the [[Northern Michigan|northern part of the Lower Peninsula of Michigan]]. He was raised by his father, Rasjid, and his stepmother, Pat, only occasionally visiting his mother, Carrie, in [[Oregon]] after she married her second husband, Lowell Brams.<ref name="pm">{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/features/interviews/9595-true-myth-a-conversation-with-sufjan-stevens/ |title=True Myth: A Conversation with Sufjan Stevens |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=February 16, 2015 |last=Dombal |first=Ryan}}</ref> Brams later became the head of Stevens' record label [[Asthmatic Kitty]].<ref name="pm"/> His brother Marzuki Stevens is a former professional road runner.<ref>{{cite web |title=Marzuki Stevens |publisher=[[Association of Road Racing Statisticians]] |url=https://more.arrs.run/runner/24395 |access-date=December 16, 2015}}</ref> Stevens is of Lithuanian and Greek descent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandjazzmusic/3654119/Liturgical-sounds-for-restaurant-place-mats.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandjazzmusic/3654119/Liturgical-sounds-for-restaurant-place-mats.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Liturgical sounds for restaurant place-mats|first=Craig|last=McLean|date=July 28, 2006|access-date=May 4, 2018|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

Stevens attended the [[Detroit Waldorf School]], Alanson Public Schools and [[Interlochen Arts Academy]], and graduated from Harbor Light Christian School. He then attended [[Hope College]] in [[Holland, Michigan]], where he graduated [[Phi Beta Kappa]], and then earned an [[Masters of Fine Arts|MFA]] from [[The New School]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Stevens |url=http://www.asthmatickitty.com/musicians.php?artistID=5 |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |access-date=October 31, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120114906/http://asthmatickitty.com/musicians.php?artistID=5 |archive-date=November 20, 2010 }}</ref>

''[[Sufjan]]'' means "comes with a sword."<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.complex.com/pigeons-and-planes/2012/12/12-things-you-didnt-know-about-sufjan-stevens/|title=12 Things You Didn't Know About Sufjan Stevens|publisher=[[Complex Networks]]}}</ref> The name most famously belonged to [[Abu Sufyan]], a figure from early Islamic history. The name was given to Stevens by the founder of [[Subud]], an interfaith spiritual community to which his parents belonged when he was born.<ref>{{cite web |last=Odland |first=Jeffrey |title=Junkmedia: An Interview with Sufjan Stevens |website=Junk Media |date=May 12, 2004 |url=http://www.junkmedia.org/index.php?i=1031 |access-date=August 27, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060813130131/http://www.junkmedia.org/index.php?i=1031 |archive-date=August 13, 2006 }}</ref>

==Career==
===Early career and the Fifty States Project (1995–2006)===
[[File:Sufjan Stevens playing banjo.jpg|thumb|right|Stevens performing at the [[Pabst Theater]] in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]]]
Stevens began his musical career as a member of [[Marzuki (band)|Marzuki]], a folk-rock band from Holland, Michigan, as well as garage band Con Los Dudes.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/> He also played (and continues to play) various instruments for [[Danielson Famile]]. During his final semester at [[Hope College]], Stevens wrote and recorded his debut solo album, ''[[A Sun Came]]'', which he released on Asthmatic Kitty Records.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/> He later moved to New York City, where he enrolled in a writing program at [[The New School for Social Research]]. During his time at the New School, Stevens developed a preoccupation with the short story form, which he believed would lead him to write a novel, but ultimately returned him to songwriting.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>

While in New York, Stevens composed and recorded the music for his second album, ''[[Enjoy Your Rabbit]]'', a [[song cycle]] based around the animals of the [[Chinese zodiac]] that delved into [[electronica]].

Stevens followed this with the album ''[[Michigan (album)|Michigan]]'', a collection of folk songs and instrumentals. It includes odes to cities including Detroit and [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]], the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan|Upper Peninsula]], and vacation areas such as [[Tahquamenon Falls]] and the [[Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore]]. Melded into the scenic descriptions and characters are his own declarations of faith, sorrow, love, and the regeneration of Michigan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sufjan Stevens, Michigan |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/reviews/story/0,,1246644,00.html |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London, UK |first=David |last=Peschek |date=June 25, 2004 |access-date=May 2, 2008}}</ref> Beginning with the album, Stevens announced his intent to write an album for each of the 50 U.S. states, which he termed the Fifty States Project. Following the release of ''Michigan'', Stevens compiled a collection of songs recorded previously into a side project, the album ''[[Seven Swans]]'', which was released in March 2004. Stevens did not leave his job in the children's book division at Time Warner until touring for ''Seven Swans''.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>

Next, he released the second in the Fifty States project, titled ''[[Illinois (Sufjan Stevens album)|Illinois]]''.<!-- DO NOT CHANGE THE NAME OF THE ALBUM: the album is correctly titled "Illinois" : see the Talk page--> Among the subjects explored on ''Illinois'' are the cities of Chicago, [[Decatur, Illinois|Decatur]] and [[Jacksonville, Illinois|Jacksonville]]; the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] of 1893, the death of a friend on [[Casimir Pulaski Day]], the poet [[Carl Sandburg]], and the serial killer [[John Wayne Gacy]]. Stevens had spent the second half of 2004 researching and writing material for the album. As with ''Michigan'', Stevens used the state of [[Illinois]] as a leaping-off point for his more personal explorations of faith, family, love, and location. Though slated for release on July 5, 2005, the album was briefly delayed by legal issues regarding the use of an image of [[Superman]] in the original album cover artwork. In the double vinyl release, a balloon sticker was placed over Superman on the cover art of the first 5,000 copies. The next printings had an empty space where the Superman image was, as with the CD release.<ref>{{cite web |title=Illinois now available on vinyl |url=http://www.asthmatickitty.com/news.php?newsID=35 |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609051229/http://asthmatickitty.com/news.php?newsID=35 |archive-date=June 9, 2007 }}</ref> ''Illinois'' was widely acclaimed and was the highest-rated album of 2005 on the [[review aggregator]] website [[Metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Best of 2005 |website=Metacritic |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/bests/2005.shtml |access-date=November 29, 2006}}</ref> The 2006 [[PLUG Independent Music Awards]] awarded Stevens with the Album of the Year, Best Album Art/Packaging, and Male Artist of the Year. ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'', ''No Ripcord'', and ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' magazine named ''Illinois'' as the editors' choice for best album of 2005, and Stevens received the 2005 Pantheon prize, awarded to noteworthy albums selling fewer than 500,000 copies, for ''Illinois''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mp3.com/news/stories/3930.html |title=Sufjan Stevens nabs Pantheon |first=Jim |last=Welte |date=March 31, 2006 |website=MP3.com |access-date=November 24, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223140103/http://www.mp3.com/news/stories/3930.html |archive-date=December 23, 2007}}</ref>

In April 2006, Stevens announced that 21 pieces of music he had culled from the ''Illinois'' recording sessions would be incorporated into a new album, called ''[[The Avalanche (Sufjan Stevens album)|The Avalanche]]'', which was released on July 11, 2006.<ref>{{cite web |first=Jonathan |last=Cohen |title=Stevens revisits 'Illinois' |website=Monsters and Critics.com |date=April 7, 2006 |url=http://music.monstersandcritics.com/news/article_1153509.php/Stevens_revisits_Illinois |access-date=November 29, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822145512/http://music.monstersandcritics.com/news/article_1153509.php/Stevens_revisits_Illinois |archive-date=August 22, 2007 }}</ref> On September 11, 2006, in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Stevens debuted a new composition, a ten-minute-plus piece titled "Majesty Snowbird."<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Stevens, Paramount Theatre; Austin, TX 09-16-2006 |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/38664-photos-sufjan-stevens-paramount-theater-austin-tx-091606 |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224081358/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/38664-photos-sufjan-stevens-paramount-theater-austin-tx-091606 |archive-date=December 24, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Video/MP3: Sufjan Stevens: "Majesty Snowbird" (Live) |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/38897-videomp3-sufjan-stevens-majesty-snowbird-live |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225040520/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/38897-videomp3-sufjan-stevens-majesty-snowbird-live |archive-date=December 25, 2007 }}</ref> On November 21, 2006, a five CD box set ''[[Songs for Christmas (Sufjan Stevens album)|Songs for Christmas]]'' was released, which contains originals and Christmas standards recorded every year since 2001 (except 2004). Stevens undertook in the project initially as an exercise to make himself 'appreciate' Christmas more.<ref>{{cite web |title=Songs For Christmas |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |date=November 21, 2006 |url=http://www.asthmatickitty.com/music.php?releaseID=63 |access-date=November 29, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061205230606/http://www.asthmatickitty.com/music.php?releaseID=63 |archive-date=December 5, 2006 }}</ref> The songs were the work of an annual collaboration between Stevens and different collaborators, including minister Vito Aiuto; the songs themselves were distributed to friends and family.

Although Stevens' subsequent work was sometimes speculated to tie into future "States" projects,<ref name='artofthestates'>{{cite news |last=Dahlen |first=Chris |url=http://www.sfweekly.com/2005-07-13/music/art-of-the-states/ |title=Art of the States |newspaper=[[SF Weekly]] |date=July 13, 2005 |access-date=August 10, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4721675 |title=Brinkley, Ark., Embraces 'The Lord God Bird' |newspaper=NPR.org |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=July 6, 2005 |access-date=August 27, 2006}}</ref> and Stevens himself would make occasional statements alluding to the future of the project,<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Yuan |first=Jada |url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/44491/ |title=Sufjan Stevens Plans Ode to New Jersey Turnpike |magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=February 24, 2008 |access-date=October 31, 2010}}</ref> Stevens later admitted that the project had been a "promotional gimmick" and not one he had seriously intended to complete.<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/oct/27/sufjan-stevens-the-bqe |title=Sufjan Stevens's symphony for New York |newspaper=The Guardian |date=October 27, 2009 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Purcell}}</ref> In November 2009, Stevens admitted to ''[[Exclaim!]]'' magazine, in regard to the fact that he recently called his fifty-state project a joke, that "I don't really have as much faith in my work as I used to, but I think that's healthy. I think it's allowed me to be less precious about how I work and write. And maybe it's okay for us to take it less seriously."<ref>{{cite web |last=Khanna |first=Vish |url=http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=138&csid2=798&fid1=42064 |title=Sufjan Stevens' Inner State |website=Exclaim! |access-date=October 31, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616215517/http://www.exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid2=798&fid1=42064&csid1=138 |archive-date=June 16, 2010 }}</ref>

===Soundtrack album and various collaborative projects (2007–2009)===
Over the 2005 winter holidays, Stevens recorded an album with [[Rosie Thomas (singer-songwriter)|Rosie Thomas]] and [[Denison Witmer]] playing banjo and providing vocals. In April 2006, Pitchfork erroneously announced that Stevens and Thomas were having a baby together, and were forced to print a retraction.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Stevens Hypothetical Tracklists |website=Stereogum |date=April 13, 2006 |url=http://www.stereogum.com/archives/002494.html |access-date=November 29, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Sufjan E-Mails Smack Down |magazine=[[Filter (magazine)|Filter]] |date=April 13, 2006 |url=http://www.filter-mag.com/news/interior.3139.html |access-date=November 29, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061027070726/http://www.filter-mag.com/news/interior.3139.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date=October 27, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jason |last=Crock |title=Interview: Sufjan Stevens |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=May 15, 2006 |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/29535/Interview_Interview_Sufjan_Stevens |access-date=November 29, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129005759/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/29535/Interview_Interview_Sufjan_Stevens |archive-date=November 29, 2006 }}</ref> Witmer and Thomas later admitted it was an April Fools' prank.<ref>{{cite web |title=April Fools |url=http://www.denisonwitmer.com/news.php?rowstart=10 |website=DenisonWitmer.com |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060418095448/http://www.denisonwitmer.com/news.php?rowstart=10 |archive-date=April 18, 2006 }}</ref> In December 2006, the collaborative recordings were digitally released by [[Nettwerk]] as a Rosie Thomas album titled ''[[These Friends of Mine (album)|These Friends of Mine]]''. The album was released in physical form on March 13, 2007.

On May 31, 2007, Asthmatic Kitty announced that Stevens would be premiering a new project titled ''[[The BQE (soundtrack)|The BQE]]'' in early November 2007. The project, dubbed a "symphonic and cinematic exploration of New York City's infamous [[Brooklyn–Queens Expressway]],"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asthmatickitty.com/news.php?newsID=222 |title=BQE: Helpers, hula hoops, and birds |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |date=November 1, 2007 |access-date=August 23, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227045618/http://www.asthmatickitty.com/news.php?newsID=222 |archive-date=December 27, 2008 }}</ref> was manifested in a live show. ''The BQE'' featured an original film by Stevens (shot in [[Super 8 film]] and standard 16 mm), while Stevens and a backing [[orchestra]] provided the live soundtrack. The performance used 36 performers which included a small band, a wind and brass ensemble, string players, horn players, and [[hula hoop]]ers. There were no lyrics to the music. ''The BQE'' was commissioned by the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]] as part of their Next Wave Festival and performed on three consecutive nights from November 1–3, 2007.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Goes High Art for Brooklyn Academy of Music |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/43301-sufjan-goes-high-art-for-brooklyn-academy-of-music |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626101057/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/43301-sufjan-goes-high-art-for-brooklyn-academy-of-music |archive-date=June 26, 2007 }}</ref>

The performance sold out the 2,109 seat BAM Opera House without any advertising.<ref>{{cite web |last=Botts |first=Nathan |url=http://www.artsjournal.com/sandow/2007/11/a_look_at_the_future.html |title=A look at the future – Sandow |website=Artsjournal.com |date=November 8, 2007 |access-date=October 31, 2010}}</ref> After three weeks of rehearsing the piece with the three dozen musicians<ref>{{cite web |url=http://asthmatickitty.com/sidebar.php?sidebarID=278 |title=Asthmatic Kitty Records : Sidebar |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |access-date=October 31, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227034524/http://asthmatickitty.com/sidebar.php?sidebarID=278 |archive-date=December 27, 2010 }}</ref> involved, he presented the 30-minute composition. ''The BQE'' was followed by an additional one hour of concert by Stevens and his orchestra. ''The BQE'' won the 2008 [[Brendan Gill]] Prize.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/30121-sufjan-wins-prestigious-prize-for-his-bqe-thing |title=Sufjan Wins Prestigious Prize for His "BQE" Thing |first=Matthew |last=Solarski |date=September 4, 2008 |website=Pitchfork |access-date=October 31, 2010}}</ref> In April 2007, in [[Brooklyn]] and [[Philadelphia]], Stevens made unannounced appearances on Thomas's tour in support of this album. In 2007, he did a Take-Away Show acoustic video session shot by [[Vincent Moon]] standing on a roof in Cincinnati.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blogotheque.net/Sufjan-Stevens-and-friends,3128 |title=Sufjan Stevens and friends @ MusicNow – Sufjan Stevens and friends @ MusicNow |website=La Blogotheque |access-date=October 31, 2010}}</ref> In 2007, he played shows sporadically, including playing at the [[Kennedy Center]] to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the [[Millennium Stage]] concerts.<ref>{{cite web |title=Live: Sufjan Stevens; Kennedy Center, Washington D.C., 5 February 2007 |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/40970-live-sufjan-stevens |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509115354/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/40970-live-sufjan-stevens |archive-date=May 9, 2007 }}</ref>

Stevens has also worked as an essayist, contributing to Asthmatic Kitty Records' "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070622223108/http://asthmatickitty.com/sidebar.php Sidebar]" feature and ''Topic Magazine''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Stevens Pens Personal Essay for Topic Magazine |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/38267-sufjan-stevens-pens-personal-essay-for-itopici-magazine |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224083307/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/38267-sufjan-stevens-pens-personal-essay-for-itopici-magazine |archive-date=December 24, 2007 }}</ref> He wrote the introduction to the 2007 edition of ''The Best American Nonrequired Reading'', a short story about his early childhood education and learning to read titled ''How I Trumped Rudolf Steiner and Overcame the Tribulations of Illiteracy, One Snickers Bar at a Time''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Pens Eggers' Nonrequired Collection Intro |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/42967-sufjan-pens-eggers-inonrequiredi-collection-intro |website=Pitchfork |access-date=June 16, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618051652/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/page/news/42967-sufjan-pens-eggers-inonrequiredi-collection-intro |archive-date=June 18, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first1=Dave |last1=Eggers |first2=Sufjan |last2=Stevens |title=The best American nonrequired reading 2007 |url=https://archive.org/details/bestamericannonr00dave_3 |url-access=registration |location=Boston|publisher=Houghton Mifflin |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-618-90281-1}}</ref> That winter, he hosted an "Xmas Song Exchange Contest" in which winner [[Alec Duffy]] won exclusive rights to the original Stevens song "Lonely Man of Winter." The track could only be heard by attending private listening parties at Duffy's home in Brooklyn and at places around the world until 2018, when Duffy negotiated with Asthmatic Kitty Records to release the song with all proceeds going towards Duffy's organization JACK.<ref>{{cite news |title=Listening to Sufjan's "The Lonely Man of Winter" in Crown Heights |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/archives/2009/02/exclusive_liste.php |newspaper=The Village Voice |access-date=February 9, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211122353/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/archives/2009/02/exclusive_liste.php |archive-date=February 11, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="hoipolloiworld.com">{{cite web |title=Hoi Polloi's Sufjan Stevens Winter Song Exclusive Listening Sessions |url=http://www.hoipolloiworld.com/Sufjan_Listening_Sessions.html |website=Hoi Polloi}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sufjan Stevens Releases Rare Song "Lonely Man of Winter": Listen |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/sufjan-stevens-rare-song-lonely-man-of-winter-is-finally-coming-out/ |website=Pitchfork|date=November 8, 2018 }}</ref>

Stevens has contributed to the music of Denison Witmer, [[Soul-Junk]], [[Half-handed Cloud]], [[Brother Danielson]], Danielson Famile, [[Serena-Maneesh]], [[Castanets (band)|Castanets]], [[Will Stratton]], [[Shannon Stephens]], [[Clare & the Reasons]], Little Scream,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/64297-little-scream-enlists-sufjan-stevens-the-nationalarcade-fire-members-sharon-van-etten-for-cult-following-lp-shares-love-as-a-weapon-video/| title= Little Scream Enlists Sufjan Stevens, The National/Arcade Fire Members, Sharon Van Etten for Cult Following LP, Shares "Love as a Weapon" Video |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |access-date=May 21, 2016 |first=Sheldon |last=Pierce| date= March 22, 2016 }}</ref> and [[Liz Janes]]. In 2007 alone, Stevens played piano on [[The National (band)|The National]]'s album ''[[Boxer (The National album)|Boxer]]'', produced and contributed many instrumental tracks to Rosie Thomas's album ''These Friends of Mine'', multiple instruments on [[Ben + Vesper]]'s album ''[[All This Could Kill You]]'' and oboe and vocals to [[David Garland (musician)|David Garland]]'s 2007 album ''[[Noise in You]]''.

His songs "The Tallest Man, The Broadest Shoulders" and "All the Trees of the Field Will Clap Their Hands" were featured in the 2006 British comedy-drama ''[[Driving Lessons]]'', starring ''[[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter]]''{{'}}s [[Julie Walters]] and [[Rupert Grint]]. In 2008, he produced ''[[Welcome to The Welcome Wagon]]'', the debut album of Brooklyn-based husband and wife duo Vito and Monique Aiuto, [[The Welcome Wagon]].

In February 2009, Stevens contributed "You Are the Blood" to the AIDS benefit album ''[[Dark Was the Night (album)|Dark Was the Night]]'' produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]]. In April 2009, Stevens uploaded a song about director [[Sofia Coppola]] online.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lindsay |first=Andrew |title=Sufjan Stevens posts song about Sofia Coppola |date=April 27, 2009 |url=http://stereokill.net/2009/04/27/sufjan-stevens-posts-song-about-sofia-coppola/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610080534/http://stereokill.net/2009/04/27/sufjan-stevens-posts-song-about-sofia-coppola/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 10, 2009 |website=Stereokill.net |access-date=April 27, 2009 }}</ref> This song was written while Stevens was in college, from a series of songs about names.

Stevens recalled:

<blockquote>A few weeks later, our dog got hit by a snowplow and I forgot all about the problem of names. Until college, when I learned to play the guitar, and, as an exercise, started writing songs (very poorly executed) in the same way that Henry Ford produced the automobile: assembly-line-style. I wrote songs for the days of the week (poor Monday!). Songs for the planets (poor Pluto!). Songs for the Apostles (poor Judas!). And, finally, when all else failed, I started a series of songs for names. [...] Each piece was a rhetorical, philosophical, musical rumination on all the possible names I had entertained years before when my parents had given me the one chance to change my own. Oh fates! I sang these songs in the privacy of my dorm room, behind closed doors, pillows and cushions stuffed in the air vents so no one would hear. And then I almost failed Latin class, my grades plummeted, my social life dissolved into ping pong tournaments in the residence halls, and, gradually, my interest in music (or anything divine, creative, fruitful, enriching) completely waned. I turned to beer. And cigarettes. And TV sitcoms. And candy bars. Oh well! A perfectly good youth wasted on junk food! That is, until a few months ago, when I came across some of the old name songs, stuffed onto tape cassettes, 4-track recorders, forgotten boxes, forgotten shelves, forgotten hard drives. It was like finding an old diary, or a high school yearbook, senior picture with lens flare and pockmarks, slightly cute and embarrassing. What was I thinking?<ref name="Stevens">{{cite web |last=Stevens |first=Sufjan |title=What's in a Name? |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |url=http://sidebar.asthmatickitty.com/archives/1867 |access-date=May 17, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525082328/http://sidebar.asthmatickitty.com/archives/1867 |archive-date=May 25, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref></blockquote>

===Solo studio albums (2009–2011)===
[[File:Sufjan Stevens, Leipzig, May 2011.jpg|alt=|190px|thumb|upright|Stevens in 2011, following his return to recording and touring in 2010 after a hiatus]]
In September 2009, Stevens began performing four new songs while on his fall tour, "All Delighted People", "Impossible Soul", "Too Much" and "Age of Adz".<ref>{{cite web |last=Stosuy |first=Brandon |title=New Sufjan Stevens – "There's Too Much Love"/"Age Of Adz"/"Impossible Souls" (Live In Ithaca) |website=Stereogum |url=http://stereogum.com/archives/video/new_sufjan_stevens__theres_too_much_love_live_in_092181.html |access-date=October 11, 2009|date=September 25, 2009 }}</ref> That year Stevens contributed to an album with his stepfather, Lowell Brams, entitled ''Music for Insomnia''. The album was released December 8, 2009.<ref>{{cite news |last=Michaels |first=Sean |title=Sufjan Stevens records album of 'background music' |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/oct/05/sufjan-stevens-background-music |access-date=October 11, 2009 |location=London |date=October 5, 2009}}</ref> On October 6, 2009, Stevens' label, Asthmatic Kitty Records, released an album of versions of his 2001 album ''Enjoy Your Rabbit'' rearranged for strings and performed by the Osso String Quartet, entitled ''[[Run Rabbit Run (album)|Run Rabbit Run]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asthmatickitty.com//news.php?newsID=474/ |url-status=dead |title=Sufjan Stevens' Enjoy Your Rabbit Reimagined By Osso As Run Rabbit Run |publisher=Asthmatic Kitty Records |date=July 9, 2009 |access-date=October 31, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904142123/http://asthmatickitty.com/news.php?newsID=474%2F |archive-date=September 4, 2011}}</ref>

In 2010, Stevens was featured on The National's album ''[[High Violet]]'', released in May, and sang backing vocals for the band on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=The National – "Afraid Of Everyone" 5/13 Letterman (TheAudioPerv.com) |via=[[YouTube]] |date=May 13, 2010}}</ref> Following the release of ''High Violet'', band frontman [[Matt Berninger]] mentioned that Stevens was recording a new album in the band's studio and that The National would appear on some of the tracks. In early August, Stevens announced North American tour dates across dozens of cities. On August 20, 2010, Stevens suddenly and unexpectedly released a new collection of tracks, the ''[[All Delighted People]]'' EP, for digital download. The EP is built around two versions of the title track, "All Delighted People".<ref>{{cite news |title=Sufjan Stevens |url=http://Sufjanstevens.bandcamp.com |date=October 12, 2010}}</ref> The EP surprisingly rose to #27 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] albums solely through its digital sales.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chart Moves: Katy Perry, Vampire Weekend, Cee-Lo, Taylor Swift |url=http://Billboard.biz |date=September 2, 2010 |access-date=March 3, 2022 |archive-date=January 6, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106162100/http://billboard.biz/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> On August 26, Asthmatic Kitty announced that Stevens would release his newest full-length album, ''[[The Age of Adz]]'', on October 12.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sufjan Stevens The Age Of Adz |website=[[Stereogum]] |date=August 26, 2010}}</ref> [[NPR]] streamed the album until it was released on October 12, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hilton |first=Robin |title=First Listen: Sufjan Stevens, 'The Age Of Adz' |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=September 26, 2010}}</ref>

The two albums featured a wide range of arrangements, from orchestral to electronic. Song lengths were also extended; the track "Djohariah" from ''All Delighted People'' is 17 minutes long, while "Impossible Soul" from ''The Age of Adz'' is 25 minutes long. The albums also feature many styles from [[disco]] to [[folk music|folk]].

Stevens has stated in interviews that in 2009 and 2010 he suffered from a mysterious debilitating virus infection that affected his nervous system. He experienced chronic pain and was forced to stop working on music for several months.<ref name="stereogum">{{cite news|last=Renshaw|first=Denny|date=October 22, 2010|title=Sufjan Reveals Health Issues, Has Career-Best Sales Week'|website=Stereogum|url=https://www.stereogum.com/553642/sufjan-reveals-health-issues-has-career-best-sales-week/news/|url-status=live}}</ref> He said: "''The Age of Adz'', is, in some ways, a result of that process of working through health issues and getting much more in touch with my physical self. That's why I think the record's really obsessed with sensation and has a hysterical melodrama to it."<ref name="exclaim">{{cite news |url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/sufjan_stevens_discusses_his_serious_issues |last=Khanna |first=Vish |title=Sufjan Stevens Discusses His "Mysterious and Debilitating" Health Issues |date=October 22, 2010 |website=[[Exclaim!]]}}</ref>

On October 12, 2010, Stevens began his North American tour in [[Montreal]], featuring virtually all new material. The tour lasted just over a month and ended on November 15, 2010, in New York City. Stevens toured Australia and New Zealand in early 2011, featured as part of the [[Sydney Festival]], and appeared on-stage with The National during the last of three sold-out Auckland shows.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |first=Bernard |last=Zuel |title=Sufjan Stevens |date=January 29, 2011}}</ref> He also toured Europe and the United Kingdom in April and May 2011, playing there for the first time in five years.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/news/latest-news/sufjan-stevens-announces-ukeuropean-tour-47719 |title=Sufjan Stevens Announces UK and European Tour |date=February 23, 2011 |website=The Line of Best Fit |access-date=December 10, 2017}}</ref> His shows mostly consisted of new material, but he did play many older tracks from ''Seven Swans'' and ''Illinois''. Stevens ended the Age of Adz tour with two shows in [[Prospect Park, Brooklyn]], New York.

On May 6, 2021, Stevens released a five-volume album of meditation music, called ''[[Convocations (album)|Convocations]]''. ===Themes===
Stevens' work is known to explore themes of love,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thefader.com/2019/05/29/sufjan-stevens-love-yourself-whole-heart-pride|date=May 29, 2019|website=[[The Fader]]|title=Sufjan Stevens shares two new songs to mark the start of Pride|last=Renshaw|first=David}}</ref> religion,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/03/sufjan-stevens-and-a-better-way-to-write-music-about-faith/388802/|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=March 29, 2015|title=How Sufjan Stevens Subverts the Stigma of Christian Music|last=Roark|first=David}}</ref> outer space,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/1474-tracking-sufjan-stevens-fascination-with-outer-space/|title=Tracking Sufjan Stevens' Fascination with Outer Space|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|date=March 28, 2017|last=Corcoran|first=Nina}}</ref> and grief.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2015/3/24/8283039/sufjan-stevens-carrie-lowell|website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|date=March 24, 2015|title=Sufjan Stevens deals with his mother's death in one of his best albums yet|last=McKinney|first=Kelsey}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2015/03/30/how-sufjan-stevens-wrestles-with-death-and-faith-in-his-new-album-carrie-and-lowell/|title=How Sufjan Stevens wrestles with death and faith in his new album 'Carrie and Lowell'|last=Hamm|first=Ryan E.C.|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 30, 2015}}</ref>

Despite many of his songs having spiritual allusions, Stevens does not identify as a [[contemporary Christian music]] artist or frequently discuss religion with the press. He told ''The Village Voice'': "I don't think music media is the real forum for theological discussions. I think I've said things and sung about things that probably weren't appropriate for this kind of form. And I just feel like it's not my work or my place to be making claims and statements because I often think it's misunderstood."<ref name="Sylvester">{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Sylvester |title=Without a Prayer |newspaper=[[The Village Voice]] |date=August 8, 2005 |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/0532,sylvester,66665,22.html |access-date=August 27, 2006}}</ref>

During a 2004 interview with Adrian Pannett for ''Comes with a Smile'' magazine, when asked how important faith was to his music, he said "I don't like talking about that stuff in the public forum because, I think, certain themes and convictions are meant for personal conversation."<ref name="All Good Naysayers, Speak up!">{{cite web |title=Comes With A Smile – Number 15 – Summer 2004 |url=http://allgoodnaysayers.net/press/reviews/comes-with-a-smile-number-15-summer-2004-review |website=All Good Naysayers, Speak up! |access-date=June 16, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722004944/http://allgoodnaysayers.net/press/reviews/comes-with-a-smile-number-15-summer-2004-review |archive-date=July 22, 2011 }}</ref> In a 2006 interview, he said "It's not so much that faith influences us as it lives in us. In every circumstance (giving a speech or tying my shoes), I am living and moving and being."<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Roark |first1=David |title=How Sufjan Stevens Subverts the Stigma of Christian Music |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/03/sufjan-stevens-and-a-better-way-to-write-music-about-faith/388802/ |access-date=March 31, 2015 |magazine=[[The Atlantic]] |date=March 29, 2015}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Stevens has resided in [[Upstate New York]] near the [[Catskill Mountains]] since 2019. Before this, he lived in New York City for 20 years.<ref name="theguardian.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/sep/25/sufjan-stevens-interview-the-ascension |last=Horner |first=Al |title='I have a sense of urgency': Sufjan Stevens wakes from the American dream |date=September 25, 2020 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=October 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2020/09/sufjan-stevens-the-ascension-interview|title=Sufjan Stevens on Making Pop Music in a Crisis|date=September 24, 2020|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|url-access=limited}}</ref> He identifies as a Christian.<ref name="pm" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thequietus.com/articles/05085-the-age-of-adz-sufjan-stevens-interview |title=Adz And It Shall Be Given Unto You: Sufjan Stevens Interviewed |website=[[The Quietus]] |access-date=August 6, 2011}}</ref> Stevens also stated in 2005 that he attended an [[Anglo-Catholic]] [[Episcopalianism|Episcopal]] church.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.avclub.com/sufjan-stevens-1798208555|title=Sufjan Stevens|last=Murray|first=Noel|work=[[The A.V. While in school, Stevens studied the oboe and English horn, which he plays on his albums.
